announced through 'chairman C. U.
Larrick that conflict with Commemoration Day exercises has caused the

MEMBER

Two weeks ago the Student Council decided by a
five to four majority to deny
the Young Communist
League an assembly. Had the
vote been nine to nothing
against the assembly we
would still have disagreed since we like to
think that we
are proponents of free speech. However,
such a close decision makes it doubly necessary to keep
the issue alive,
for we believe that the four men representing
the minority on the council also represent an
overwhelming majority of the student body.
The answer to the Y. C. L letter was
unsatisfactory
and evasive of the issue involved-Hwhe
ther or not some
Hopkins undergrads voluntarily can succumb
to.a Communist propagandist for fifty minutes and
not be shaken
from their original orthodox opinions.
The important thing now is to keep this
issue
A serious, though perhaps indirect, blow has
been struck
against free speech at the Hopkins. Such a blow
must be
fought not only because of its immediate
results but
because of the ultimate repercussions which
are certain
to result.
It is to be hoped that the Student Council
will reconsider its divided view or that liberal campus
organizations will press the cause of the Y. C. L.
.
At any rate let's not dismiss the affair lightly;
such a
vital issue is not one'to be forgotten quickly.
—L.W.B.

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, FRIDAY, FEBRUARY 11, 1938

KAPPA SIG MEETS ANNUAL HANDBALL
KAPPA ALPHA IN TOURNEY EXPECTED
IMPORTANT GAME TO BEGIN THIS WEEK

CAMPUS
CAVORTINGS

The final two weeks of inter-fraternity basketball competition will begin
tomorrow with the victors of all three
leagues still in doubt.
Phi Gain, Phi Alpha Undefeated
In league "A" bath Phi Gam and
Phi Alpha are undefeated and providing they win their games tomorrow, the former against D. U. and the
latter against A. E. Pi, they will clash
the following Saturday to decide the
league champ.
Phi Gam seems to be a slight favorite over Phi Alpha as it has practically the same team that won the
championship last yew. Nevertheless,
Phi Alpha can always be counted on
for a battle.
A. T. 0. meets S. P. E. in the other
league "A" game.
Kappa Sig Meets Kappa Alpha
There are also two undefeated
teams in league "B" namely Kappa
Sig and Kappa Alpha and they will
clash tomorrow in what should decide
the league "B" champions. At present it looks as if Kappa Sig will represent league "B" in the play-offs.
Led by McGovern and Day, Kappa
Sig has scored 85 points in 3 games
while holding their opponents to 6
points. Although Kappa Alpha doesn't
have quite as impressive a record as
Kappa Sig, they defeated the strong
Pi Lam quintet and as a result bears
watching.
If Kappa Sig beats Kappa Alpha
tomorrow they will still have to beat
the strong Pi Lam 'quintet. Other
games in league "B" pit A. D. Phi
against Beta Theta Pi and Pi Lam
gainst Delta Phi.

Interest Spreading
While interest in the sport is prevalent in the north, some southern
universities have displayed increasing interest in the sport. These
schools the Jays will meet in the
course of the season.

Singing, shouting college students
in Denver hired their driver to stay
sober for them. When a police officer
questioned him he said, "They hired
•me to drive as long as the party
lasted. I'm working my way through
college for fellow students who like
to drink."
Syracuse Unlversity school of journalism students passed
,a petition
among fellow students in a "gullibility test." They found 115 seniors
would sign a paper that at the start
read like a proposal to eliminate final exams for seniors but ended up
with a promise to serve five years
in a chain gang. Said the journalism
students: "They'll sign anything."
The pleasing personality that influences people is born, not made, in
the opinion of Dr. Howard W. Haggard, professor of applied psychology
at Yale University. Personality and
genius are inborn, he says.

MEMBER

Two weeks ago the Student Council decided by a
five to four majority to deny
the Young Communist
League an assembly. Had the
vote been nine to nothing
against the assembly we
would still have disagreed since we like to
think that we
are proponents of free speech. However,
such a close decision makes it doubly necessary to keep
the issue alive,
for we believe that the four men representing
the minority on the council also represent an
overwhelming majority of the student body.
The answer to the Y. C. L letter was
unsatisfactory
and evasive of the issue involved-Hwhe
ther or not some
Hopkins undergrads voluntarily can succumb
to.a Communist propagandist for fifty minutes and
not be shaken
from their original orthodox opinions.
The important thing now is to keep this
issue
A serious, though perhaps indirect, blow has
been struck
against free speech at the Hopkins. Such a blow
must be
fought not only because of its immediate
results but
because of the ultimate repercussions which
are certain
to result.
It is to be hoped that the Student Council
will reconsider its divided view or that liberal campus
organizations will press the cause of the Y. C. L.
.
At any rate let's not dismiss the affair lightly;
such a
vital issue is not one'to be forgotten quickly.
—L.W.B.

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, FRIDAY, FEBRUARY 11, 1938

KAPPA SIG MEETS ANNUAL HANDBALL
KAPPA ALPHA IN TOURNEY EXPECTED
IMPORTANT GAME TO BEGIN THIS WEEK

CAMPUS
CAVORTINGS

The final two weeks of inter-fraternity basketball competition will begin
tomorrow with the victors of all three
leagues still in doubt.
Phi Gain, Phi Alpha Undefeated
In league "A" bath Phi Gam and
Phi Alpha are undefeated and providing they win their games tomorrow, the former against D. U. and the
latter against A. E. Pi, they will clash
the following Saturday to decide the
league champ.
Phi Gam seems to be a slight favorite over Phi Alpha as it has practically the same team that won the
championship last yew. Nevertheless,
Phi Alpha can always be counted on
for a battle.
A. T. 0. meets S. P. E. in the other
league "A" game.
Kappa Sig Meets Kappa Alpha
There are also two undefeated
teams in league "B" namely Kappa
Sig and Kappa Alpha and they will
clash tomorrow in what should decide
the league "B" champions. At present it looks as if Kappa Sig will represent league "B" in the play-offs.
Led by McGovern and Day, Kappa
Sig has scored 85 points in 3 games
while holding their opponents to 6
points. Although Kappa Alpha doesn't
have quite as impressive a record as
Kappa Sig, they defeated the strong
Pi Lam quintet and as a result bears
watching.
If Kappa Sig beats Kappa Alpha
tomorrow they will still have to beat
the strong Pi Lam 'quintet. Other
games in league "B" pit A. D. Phi
against Beta Theta Pi and Pi Lam
gainst Delta Phi.

universities have displayed increasing interest in the sport. These
schools the Jays will meet in the
course of the season.

Singing, shouting college students

Syracuse Unlversity school of journalism students passed
,a petition
among fellow students in a "gullibility test." They found 115 seniors
would sign a paper that at the start
read like a proposal to eliminate final exams for seniors but ended up
with a promise to serve five years
in a chain gang. Said the journalism
students: "They'll sign anything."
The pleasing personality that influences people is born, not made, in
the opinion of Dr. Howard W. Haggard, professor of applied psychology
at Yale University. Personality and
genius are inborn, he says.

It's the tops, so they say
And it's led by Glen Gray."
